awd_titl_txt: CPS: Synergy: Collaborative Research: Design and Control of High-performance Provably-safe Autonomy-enabled Dynamic Transportation Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
During the last decade, we have witnessed a rapid penetration of autonomous systems technology into aerial, road, underwater, and sea vehicles. The autonomy assumed by these vehicles holds the potential to increase performance significantly, for instance, by reducing delays and increasing capacity, while enhancing safety, in a number of transportation systems. However, to exploit the full potential of these autonomy-enabled transportation systems, we must rethink transportation networks and control algorithms that coordinate autonomous vehicles operating on such networks. This project focuses on the design and operation of autonomy-enabled transportation networks that provide provable guarantees on achieving high performance and maintaining safety at all times. The foundational problems arising in this domain involve taking into account the physics governing the vehicles in order to coordinate them using cyber means. 

This research effort aims to advance the science of cyber-physical systems by following a unique and radical approach, drawing inspiration and techniques from non-equilibrium statistical mechanics and self-organizing systems, and blending this inspiration with the foundational tools of queueing theory, control theory, and optimization. This approach may allow orders of magnitude improvement in the servicing capabilities of various transportation networks for moving goods or people. The applications include the automation of warehouses, factory floors, sea ports, aircraft carrier decks, transportation networks involving driverless cars, drone-enabled delivery networks, air traffic management, and military logistics networks. The project also aims to start a new wave of classes and tutorials that will create trained engineers and a research community in the area of safe and efficient transportation networks enabled by autonomous cyber-physical systems.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
Autonomous vehicles hold the potential to transform mobility. More than a billion vehicle that are on the roads today experience congestion, create pollution, and render cities unlivable. Autonomous, shared, electric mobility of the future may allow people to move through cities far more efficiently and sustainably than it is possible today. This project developed a foundational analysis of future autonomy-enabled transportation systems towards better understanding their potential towards efficiency and sustainability. In this regard, first, we developed a theory to understand their interaction in crowded hubs such as intersections. We derived the maximum efficiency that can possibly achieved while coordinating streams of vehicles arriving at an intersection where complete coordination is possible. We show that the efficiency is far better than what their human-driven counterparts can achieve when coordinating via traffic lights. Second, we developed a theory to study autonomy-enabled transportation in links that connect these hubs. For instance, we have looked at how cooperating vehicles can reduce their energy consumption and emissions by platooning. In this regard, we derived the efficiency-sustainability tradeoffs. Finally, we developed a core theory that considers this system as a whole. We observe that the system operates much like an out-of-equilibrium systems of statistical mechanics. Utilizing developed in the physics literature, we devise methods to better understand the emergent behavior of these systems. 

 


Last Modified: 04/14/2022
Modified by: Sertac Karaman
